fields.standfirst: British aeronautical engineer who played a key role in Nasa and America‚Äôs space race
fields.trailText: British aeronautical engineer who played a key role in Nasa and America‚Äôs space race
fields.body:
At 11am on 20 February 1959, the Canadian prime minister John Diefenbaker announced the axing of the revolutionary Avro Arrow aircraft project. The fighter was enormously expensive, but had sustained 25,000 hi-tech Canadian jobs. By 3pm on that day Avro was telling employees (via its PA system) that they were being laid off. Among the thousands to go was John Hodge, a British engineer born in Leigh-on-Sea, Essex.

The subsequent career of Hodge, who has died aged 92, embodied the aspiration, triumph, catastrophe ‚Äì and planning ‚Äì that made up the saga of space flight during the cold war years, when scientists from across the west were drawn into that vast American enterprise. By 1969, in the wake of Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin‚Äôs Moon landing, the BBC‚Äôs space correspondent Reginald Turnill, citing the ‚Äúanglonaut‚Äù Hodge as an example, was telling Radio 4 listeners that the ‚Äúastonishing thing about America‚Äôs post-Apollo space plans was that they were largely being drawn up by Englishmen‚Äù.

By then Hodge was managing Nasa‚Äôs advanced missions programme. ‚ÄúWhat is needed is some sort of reusable system, a space shuttle,‚Äù Hodge told the Guardian journalist Adam Raphael just before the Apollo 11 triumph. With the right money, he went on, it was not unreasonable ‚Äúto think that we will have landed on Mars before the end of the century‚Äù.

Booms and slumps in aspiration, funding, and geopolitics were the stuff of the space race. In 1958, reacting to the Soviet Union‚Äôs launch of Sputnik 1 the previous year, President Dwight D Eisenhower had created Nasa (the National Aeronautics and Space Administration) and, within it, the Space Task Group (later the Johnson Space Centre, Houston). Manned spaceflight was on the agenda, yet, early in 1959, the STG was still only 100-strong.

Avro Canada‚Äôs collision with reality provide American aerospace with its biggest windfall since 1945, when the US had scooped up the alumni of the Nazi rocket programme. Nasa recruited 32 of Avro‚Äôs leading Canadian, Irish, French and British technologists, including Hodge. He was appointed technical assistant to Chris Kraft, the chief of the STG‚Äôs operations division. Kraft later became Nasa‚Äôs first flight director, and Hodge succeeded him to become its second, in 1963.

In May 1961 ‚Äì after the cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin‚Äôs earth orbit ‚Äì Eisenhower‚Äôs successor, John Kennedy, had pledged that Americans would land on the Moon before the end of the decade. Nasa‚Äôs Gemini programme honed the technology for the Moon attempt, but in March 1966 it also generated the first potentially fatal crisis. Hodge was Houston‚Äôs flight director for the Gemini VIII mission of Armstrong and David Scott. The operation entailed the first docking with an Agena target vehicle, but the combined craft pitched out of control.

The astronauts separated the capsules, but the roll persisted, at 360 degrees a second (a thruster rocket had short-circuited). Eventually Armstrong and Scott switched off the main thrusters, brought Gemini VIII back under control ‚Äì and used a lot of fuel. Hodge made a brave, and crucial, decision, terminating the scheduled three-day mission on the capsule‚Äôs seventh orbit.

As he recalled in an oral history interview for the Johnson centre: ‚ÄúIf anybody ever asks, ‚ÄòWhat did I do in the space program?‚Äô, it was make sure that Neil Armstrong was around to fly on Apollo.‚Äù

Worse followed, in what became a defining moment for Nasa, Hodge, the consummate planner, and his colleagues. The Apollo programme, which had begun in 1961, aimed to fulfil the Kennedy pledge. In January 1967, with Hodge as flight director and appalled witness, Apollo 1, thanks to faulty design and construction, caught fire during a rehearsal, killing the astronauts Roger Chaffee, Edward White and Virgil Grissom.

In Charles Murray and Catherine Bly Cox‚Äôs book Apollo: The Race to the Moon (1989), Hodge, with his flight-testing background, reflected on a tragedy that had shattered some members of the team. ‚ÄúYou understand that risk is there,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand when it happens it‚Äôs terrible ‚Ä¶ You wish it didn‚Äôt happen, you wish you were smarter, but you know it‚Äôs going to happen, and so you learn to live with that.‚Äù

In the wake of Apollo 11 and the triumphant mission of Armstrong, Aldrin and Michael Collins, enthusiasm for the Moon adventure flagged. The cold war impetus was lacking ‚Äì both sides had nuclear-tipped rockets aplenty to destroy the planet ‚Äì and Soviet-US space collaboration grew.

Hodge was a flight director until 1968, left Nasa in 1970 and took posts with the Transportation Development Corporation of Ontario and the Department of Transportation in Washington DC. But in 1981, as he had predicted, the first space shuttle took flight, and in the Reagan era, in 1982, he was back with Nasa, directing the Space Station Task Force. In 1984-85 he worked on the Space Station Freedom project ‚Äì which would evolve into the International Space Station.

Hodge, the son of John and Emily Hodge, was educated at Minchenden grammar school in Southgate, north London. In 1949 he gained a first-class degree in engineering from the Northampton Institute (now City, University of London). He then spent two years in the aerodynamics department at Vickers-Armstrong in Weybridge, Surrey, before moving to Avro Canada in Toronto.

From 1987 to 2003, he was president of an international management consultancy, JD Hodge. He received eight awards from Nasa, including its medal for exceptional service in 1967 and 1969. City University awarded him an honorary doctorate in 1966, and he was an associate fellow of the Royal Aeronautical Society.

In 1952 Hodge married Audrey Cox. She survives him, as do their children, Robert, Janice, Nicola and Jonathan.

fields.headline: The Startup Wife by Tahmima Anam review ‚Äì trouble in Utopia
fields.standfirst: A man takes the credit for his brilliant coder wife‚Äôs invention in a savage satire of tech startups
fields.trailText: A man takes the credit for his brilliant coder wife‚Äôs invention in a savage satire of tech startups
fields.body:
It‚Äôs easy to recall a time when Tahmima Anam‚Äôs new novel, a pacy satire set in a secretive tech ‚Äúincubator‚Äù, might have passed for science fiction. Not any longer. From the all-consuming social media platform that hogs centre stage to the deadly pandemic that looms over its ending, The Startup Wife pulses with up-to-the-minute topicality. Real-world parallels can be found for even its most far-fetched notions. Software that channels the voice of a deceased loved one? Microsoft patented something very similar at the start of this year (note to IT bosses: Anam‚Äôs version goes catastrophically awry).

Look beyond the bleeding-edge technology and apocalyptic anxieties, however, and you‚Äôll find a cautionary tale as old as time: a woman invents something, a guy takes the credit. In keeping with the credo of its backdrop (‚ÄúChange is everything‚Äù), Anam is out to disrupt this narrative, embedding her efforts in a quest for love and self-determination, and swiping as she goes at an industry in which innovation has far outpaced regulation, leaving ethics in the dust. The end result may not be entirely persuasive philosophically, but as high-octane entertainment that hits notes poignant as well as savagely witty, it soars.

A boardroom is reachable only via trampoline; nudist networking events feature 'cuddle puddles'; and cat baptisms abound

It all begins when Asha Ray, an MIT coding whiz and the daughter of immigrant pharmacists, runs into her teen crush, Cyrus Jones. The aloof hottie who ignored her throughout high school is now an itinerant ‚Äúhumanist spirit guide‚Äù, crafting personalised rituals that allow the non-religious to meaningfully mark life‚Äôs milestones. A whirlwind romance ensues, and suddenly it‚Äôs as if everything that once seemed impossible is within Asha‚Äôs reach. Lovestruck, she has an idea. What if she ditches her PhD and writes an algorithm to channel Cyrus‚Äôs brilliance, offering bespoke rituals and allowing followers to connect with like-minded soul-searchers?

The pair get hitched on a whim and their startup is born. They call the platform WAI, pronounced ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and standing for ‚ÄúWe Are Infinite‚Äù. Cyrus‚Äôs best friend, a damaged Wasp named Jules, signs up for the ride and they move to New York, where they‚Äôre given desk space at Utopia, an exclusive tech incubator. All-nighters, multimillion-dollar investments and cult-like adoration follow, together with abrupt ‚Äì if not unforeseen ‚Äì reversals of fortune both professional and marital.

Related: Tahmima Anam ‚ÄòAs a woman, I‚Äôm aware of the limitations of tech‚Äô

Anam is herself the wife of a startup founder and her detailed sendups are all the funnier for feeling so plausible. A boardroom is reachable only via trampoline; nudist networking events feature ‚Äúcuddle puddles‚Äù; and cat baptisms abound.

Asha‚Äôs coding, meanwhile, is depicted in much the same way that writing is shown in films ‚Äì lots of tap-tap-tapping fuelled by hemp ‚Äúmylkshakes‚Äù. That‚Äôs fair enough, but other features of the novel are similarly skated over, including supposedly charismatic Cyrus, who‚Äôs initially described as ‚Äúmostly human, a little bit cartoon, a tiny bit ghost‚Äù, and doesn‚Äôt advance much thereafter, merely becoming more obnoxious.

To an extent, this reinforces the novel‚Äôs critique of the tech scene, and yet glimpses of Asha‚Äôs family ‚Äì the sister who ‚Äúrocks‚Äù a hijab, their Bangladeshi mother who‚Äôd rather she donned a bikini (‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what America is for‚Äù) ‚Äì are so vivid in their homeliness they can leave the reader pining for the immersive complexities of Anam‚Äôs Bengal trilogy.

By the novel‚Äôs end, a different mood prevails. Asha can‚Äôt decide whether she‚Äôs been betrayed or merely sidelined at WAI; all she knows is that she isn‚Äôt about to let Cyrus take the credit. ‚ÄúI gave him power over me,‚Äù she fumes. ‚ÄúI gave him all the privilege in the world so that he could turn around and mess me up.‚Äù

It‚Äôs an interesting response. While it doesn‚Äôt altogether fit with how the story unfolds, and it certainly isn‚Äôt going to help tech address its chronic and very real women problem (not necessarily fiction‚Äôs job anyway), it does disrupt the familiar feeling of disempowerment that comes with victimhood. It also feels true that to Asha, amid the glossy allure of Utopia, any level of unvarnished authenticity seems downright subversive.

‚Ä¢ The Startup Wife by Tahmima Anam is published by Canongate (¬£14.99). To support the Guardian order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply

results.webTitle: Mare of Easttown: 20 questions the finale must answer

fields.headline: Mare of Easttown: 20 questions the finale must answer
fields.standfirst: Who‚Äôs in the photograph? And just what is in those journals? As the Kate Winslet thriller comes to a close, here are the mysteries we‚Äôre desperate to see solved
fields.trailText: Who‚Äôs in the photograph? And just what is in those journals? As the Kate Winslet thriller comes to a close, here are the mysteries we‚Äôre desperate to see solved
fields.body:
Warning: this article contains spoilers for episodes one to six of Mare of Easttown.

Mare of Easttown has become a bona fide phenomenon. A thriller revolving around an aloof, small-town detective tracking down the perps of the sexual abuse and murder of girls is pretty much the least original idea there is, but its combination of phenomenal performances (Kate Winslet is one of the best actors working today), surprising comic chops (Jean Smart is hilarious) and breadth of suspects has proved gripping. The show even has Stephen King hooked. Who knew a bunch of bearded men in flannel shirts could be this interesting?

Here is everything we need to learn in the final episode.

Who is in the photograph?

The outline looks like two people in bed: one taking the photograph and a figure lying in the background. Does it reveal a romantic involvement? Or is the figure in the background a child? If that were the case, presumably it would be DJ and the figure in the foreground might be the real father.

What is clear is that this photograph must undermine Mare‚Äôs thinking significantly if Chief Carter needs to call her right away. I am not convinced it is just: ‚ÄúYou have the wrong brother!‚Äù I reckon the person in the photograph is closely related to Mare.

What exactly happened at the Ross family reunion?

John told Billy during the ‚Äúconfession‚Äù scene that Mare ‚Äúknew what had gone on up in the cabins‚Äù. But we are still not sure, even though it has been mapped out as Billy and Erin either starting a relationship there or consummating it. But John is suspicious as hell ‚Äì and he was there, too. Might the relationship and the necklace relate to him, not his brother?

Kenny told the police during a jail visit that it was Billy‚Äôs suggestion that he and Erin stay in his cabin. This might be because Billy wanted to be close to Erin. But it could be that Billy was trying to protect Erin from John if it is, in fact, John who is the scoundrel. Meanwhile, Kenny wasn‚Äôt exactly treating his daughter right, so questions must be asked of him, too.

Did they need a reunion when they see each other every day?

A very good question.

Is Billy guilty?

The blood all over him isn‚Äôt a great look, but his confession was coerced by Suspicious John in a way that probably counts as duress. But if Billy is innocent, why confess?

Perhaps he is involved in some way, but didn‚Äôt pull the trigger. Is he partly responsible because he helped the killer move the body, or does he simply feel responsible for her demise? Was he was so drunk that he can‚Äôt remember what happened, which has enabled John to persuade him he did it? It may even be that Billy has blood on him from an attempt to save Erin.

Is John guilty?

John is hugely suspicious, but at the moment he feels too suspicious to be the culprit. He might well be DJ‚Äôs father, though. That said, he did seem eager to give himself an alibi under the pretence of giving Frank an alibi ‚Äì even producing the photograph of a drunken Frank on his phone.

Is John even having an affair?

Probably not, for three reasons. First, Lori told Mare she didn‚Äôt notice any signs of an affair; second, Ryan didn‚Äôt say he knew John was having an affair ‚Äì he just nodded when Lori suggested it; and third, John told his father that Lori ‚Äúthinks‚Äù he is having an affair again.

If John isn‚Äôt having an affair, what is the secret between Ryan and John?

Some think John might turn out to be a serial abuser: he might be abusing his son, Ryan; his cousin‚Äôs daughter, Erin; and might even have abused his brother, Billy, during their childhood. This could be why Billy yells at him that someone needs to hold him ‚Äúaccountable‚Äù.

Can we trust Lori?

The thought of the lovely Jenny from Ally McBeal being a baddie is tough to accept. However, she told Mare that Billy had confessed to being DJ‚Äôs father ‚Äì but we didn‚Äôt see Billy confess this. So, unless that happened offscreen ‚Äì which would be a big omission from the writer, Brad Inglesby ‚Äì either she or John made it up.

The way John implored her to keep things from Mare to ‚Äúprotect our family‚Äù suggests she knows a fair bit.

Who was the kid getting his face painted at the fair, staring at Betty Carroll and creeping her out?

Forgot about him, didn‚Äôt you? Random teen ‚Äì or BRUTAL KILLER?

Is the murder weapon relevant?

Almost certainly, given that the ballistics guy was parachuted in to a single scene to tell us that the gun was an old-issue police weapon discontinued decades ago.

Who owns the other half of the heart pendant?

This will answer the DJ father question ‚Äì and reveal who has cringeworthy taste in jewellery.

Will DJ ever get his ear surgery?

Who knows. If the US had a decent public healthcare system, perhaps all of this could have been avoided.

Is Richard a baddie or a goodie?

Richard doesn‚Äôt seem suspicious to me. But Guy Pearce is quite a big name to have nothing to do with the main plot. Perhaps he is there to prove that good men exist. Either way, it was brutal for Mare not only to ditch him for a date with Zabel, but to ditch him on his birthday. It seems likely that Richard and Mare will have some kind of happy ending as part of Mare‚Äôs personal growth arc.

Will Richard ever write another book?

Well, he certainly has new material, with the bodies piling up.

What about the dodgy deacon, Mark?

Perhaps the dude who has done himself the least favours. Don‚Äôt lie constantly then return to the scene of the crime, pal ‚Äì that is rule 101.

Will Carrie get custody of Drew?

She is doing her best ‚Äì working two jobs and staying clean ‚Äì and good luck to her. It is possible the extremely stressful bath scene was a moment of realisation that she would find single motherhood difficult. It might open the door to more cooperation with Mare and Mare‚Äôs mother, Helen.

Where was Dylan on the night of the murder?

Brianna (booooo!) admitted that Dylan was not in the house in the middle of the night. Time is important. When Zabel admitted that the case on he made his name wasn‚Äôt really his achievement ‚Äì and that he had missed a crucial hour in the timeline ‚Äì alarm bells should have started ringing. All the lead characters have given their night-of-the-murder timelines to the police ‚Äì and we know Mare‚Äôs, because Helen chastised her for coming home ‚Äúat 3.30 in the morning‚Äù. Somewhere, there will be time unaccounted for.

What is in the journals?

A key question. Doesn‚Äôt look good that Dylan forbade Jess from reading them, especially if ‚Äì as we must presume ‚Äì he knew what was in them.

Is the dining room in Mare‚Äôs house underutilised?

Without question. Could make a great study, given there is already a sizeable table in the kitchen.

What will we do when the show ends?

It is a mystery.

The finale of Mare of Easttown airs in the US on 30 May at 10pm on HBO, and in the UK on Monday 31 May at 9pm on Sky Atlantic/Now TV

The show even has Stephen King hooked. Who knew a bunch of bearded men in flannel shirts could be this interesting? Here is everything we need to learn in the final episode. Who is in the photograph? The outline looks like two people in bed: one taking the photograph and a figure lying in the background. Does it reveal a romantic involvement? Or is the figure in the background a child? If that were the case, presumably it would be DJ and the figure in the foreground might be the real father. What is clear is that this photograph must undermine Mare‚Äôs thinking significantly if Chief Carter needs to call her right away. I am not convinced it is just: ‚ÄúYou have the wrong brother!‚Äù I reckon the person in the photograph is closely related to Mare. What exactly happened at the Ross family reunion? John told Billy during the ‚Äúconfession‚Äù scene that Mare ‚Äúknew what had gone on up in the cabins‚Äù. But we are still not sure, even though it has been mapped out as Billy and Erin either starting a relationship there or consummating it. But John is suspicious as hell ‚Äì and he was there, too. Might the relationship and the necklace relate to him, not his brother? Kenny told the police during a jail visit that it was Billy‚Äôs suggestion that he and Erin stay in his cabin. This might be because Billy wanted to be close to Erin. But it could be that Billy was trying to protect Erin from John if it is, in fact, John who is the scoundrel. Meanwhile, Kenny wasn‚Äôt exactly treating his daughter right, so questions must be asked of him, too. Did they need a reunion when they see each other every day? A very good question. Is Billy guilty? The blood all over him isn‚Äôt a great look, but his confession was coerced by Suspicious John in a way that probably counts as duress. But if Billy is innocent, why confess? Perhaps he is involved in some way, but didn‚Äôt pull the trigger. Is he partly responsible because he helped the killer move the body, or does he simply feel responsible for her demise? Was he was so drunk that he can‚Äôt remember what happened, which has enabled John to persuade him he did it? It may even be that Billy has blood on him from an attempt to save Erin. Is John guilty? John is hugely suspicious, but at the moment he feels too suspicious to be the culprit. He might well be DJ‚Äôs father, though. That said, he did seem eager to give himself an alibi under the pretence of giving Frank an alibi ‚Äì even producing the photograph of a drunken Frank on his phone. Is John even having an affair? Probably not, for three reasons. First, Lori told Mare she didn‚Äôt notice any signs of an affair; second, Ryan didn‚Äôt say he knew John was having an affair ‚Äì he just nodded when Lori suggested it; and third, John told his father that Lori ‚Äúthinks‚Äù he is having an affair again. If John isn‚Äôt having an affair, what is the secret between Ryan and John? Some think John might turn out to be a serial abuser: he might be abusing his son, Ryan; his cousin‚Äôs daughter, Erin; and might even have abused his brother, Billy, during their childhood. This could be why Billy yells at him that someone needs to hold him ‚Äúaccountable‚Äù. Can we trust Lori? The thought of the lovely Jenny from Ally McBeal being a baddie is tough to accept. However, she told Mare that Billy had confessed to being DJ‚Äôs father ‚Äì but we didn‚Äôt see Billy confess this. So, unless that happened offscreen ‚Äì which would be a big omission from the writer, Brad Inglesby ‚Äì either she or John made it up. The way John implored her to keep things from Mare to ‚Äúprotect our family‚Äù suggests she knows a fair bit. Who was the kid getting his face painted at the fair, staring at Betty Carroll and creeping her out? Forgot about him, didn‚Äôt you? Random teen ‚Äì or BRUTAL KILLER? Is the murder weapon relevant? Almost certainly, given that the ballistics guy was parachuted in to a single scene to tell us that the gun was an old-issue police weapon discontinued decades ago. Who owns the other half of the heart pendant? This will answer the DJ father question ‚Äì and reveal who has cringeworthy taste in jewellery. Will DJ ever get his ear surgery? Who knows. If the US had a decent public healthcare system, perhaps all of this could have been avoided. Is Richard a baddie or a goodie? Richard doesn‚Äôt seem suspicious to me. But Guy Pearce is quite a big name to have nothing to do with the main plot. Perhaps he is there to prove that good men exist. Either way, it was brutal for Mare not only to ditch him for a date with Zabel, but to ditch him on his birthday. It seems likely that Richard and Mare will have some kind of happy ending as part of Mare‚Äôs personal growth arc. Will Richard ever write another book? Well, he certainly has new material, with the bodies piling up. What about the dodgy deacon, Mark? Perhaps the dude who has done himself the least favours. Don‚Äôt lie constantly then return to the scene of the crime, pal ‚Äì that is rule 101. Will Carrie get custody of Drew? She is doing her best ‚Äì working two jobs and staying clean ‚Äì and good luck to her. It is possible the extremely stressful bath scene was a moment of realisation that she would find single motherhood difficult. It might open the door to more cooperation with Mare and Mare‚Äôs mother, Helen. Where was Dylan on the night of the murder? Brianna (booooo!) admitted that Dylan was not in the house in the middle of the night. Time is important. When Zabel admitted that the case on he made his name wasn‚Äôt really his achievement ‚Äì and that he had missed a crucial hour in the timeline ‚Äì alarm bells should have started ringing. All the lead characters have given their night-of-the-murder timelines to the police ‚Äì and we know Mare‚Äôs, because Helen chastised her for coming home ‚Äúat 3.30 in the morning‚Äù. Somewhere, there will be time unaccounted for. What is in the journals? A key question. Doesn‚Äôt look good that Dylan forbade Jess from reading them, especially if ‚Äì as we must presume ‚Äì he knew what was in them. Is the dining room in Mare‚Äôs house underutilised? Without question. Could make a great study, given there is already a sizeable table in the kitchen. What will we do when the show ends? It is a mystery.
